title: O.I. Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included provision for $ 180,000 of unusual expenses related to settlement of patent infringement allegation, in the quarter and 6 months.

title: Royals Put McReynolds On 15-Day Disabled List
description: Kansas City left fielder KEVIN McREYNOLDS, one of three players acquired from the Mets in the deal for BRET SABERHAGEN and BILL PECOTA, has been put on the 15-day disabled list with a slight separation of his right shoulder.

title: STATE DEPT. ASKS WAR CRIMES INQUIRY INTO BOSNIA CAMPS
description: Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger said today that reports of atrocities at detention centers in Bosnia and Herzegovina were "profoundly disturbing" and called for a war-crimes investigation.

title: It's Out of the Realm From Out of Nowhere
description: Racing's house of upsets produced its biggest one of the Saratoga season today when the 38-1 long shot Out of the Realm outran the favored Montreal Marty to win the $119,000 Albany Handicap for 3-year-olds bred in New York State.

title: Chiquita Brands International reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: First Mortgage Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Utility Faces Payout Cuts
description: The Illinois Power Company said yesterday that it might have to eliminate dividends on common and preferred stock if state regulators followed through on a preliminary decision and disallowed some costs on the company's new Clinton nuclear plant. Shares in the company closed down $4.75, at $20.25, after the announcement. Trading was suspended for three hours at the company's request so that the announcement could be made, and at one point the share price dropped to $19.75.

title: FastComm Communications Corp. reports earnings for Year to April 30
description: b-After a charge of $ 700,000 in connection with the acquisition of the Time Machine from from Watch Hill Research in addition to a loss from operations.c-Net income

title: Gaylord Container reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a $ 10 million charge for one-time costs associated with the acquisition of the remaining ownership interests of Gaylord Bag Partnership and Bay Sheets Inc., for both the quarter and 9 months.c-Included a pretax charge of $ 125.2 million related to the write-down of assets at the Antioch, Calif., east mill, which was idled in February 1991, for both the quarter and 9 months.The company's 1991 tables have been restated to reflect the consolidation of Gaylord Bag Partnership's results.

title: Plum Creek Timber L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Heist (C.H.) Corp.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to June 28
Pirates Rookie Revived by Knuckler
description: There are some things that never change. Laundry, for instance. Clothes get dirty, the wash piles up. Pitch a whopper of a game in your major league debut -- complete game, no earned runs, 10 strikeouts -- get your mug on national television, and still the smelly socks don't disappear miraculously.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The 827-seat theater in Washington known as the Arena Stage is being renamed the Fichandler Stage to honor two of its founders, ZELDA and THOMAS C. FICHANDLER. The dedication ceremony will be in October.

title: Real Women Are Honored in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: A Break for Poor Children
description: America is the land of the Big Mac, the stupendous pizza, the foot-long hot dog -- and five million children who go to bed hungry. It is also the land where happy families are the stuff of TV sitcoms -- and dysfunctional families the stuff of countless childhoods. Today the House of Representatives has an extraordinary chance to help these kids by playing Robin Hood. Only this won't be robbery. This will be fairness.

title: American Israeli Paper Mills Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
U.S. Jury Indicts 4 Police Officers In King Beating
description: Three months after a state jury acquitted four Los Angeles police officers on nearly all charges in the beating of Rodney G. King, a verdict that set off deadly riots, a Federal grand jury here has indicted the same four men on Federal charges of violating Mr. King's civil rights.

title: Paint-Your-Own Pottery
description: LAST November, when Emily Goodman opened Pull Cart, a studio where people can paint their own decorations on bisque bowls, mugs, plates and tiles and have them glazed and fired in her kiln, she rented a 400-square-foot space. Since then, 700 customers have come to paint assorted pieces, sometimes with the help of the manager, Cynthia Higgins, left. Six weeks ago, Ms. Goodman moved to 31 West 21st Street in Chelsea, a space that is 2,000 square feet. She has 200 objects to choose from.

title: Astronauts Abandon Test of Tethered Satellite
description: Like fishermen at the end of a luckless day, the Atlantis astronauts yesterday abandoned their fruitless efforts to cast a satellite out into space on a 12-mile line and slowly reeled it back into the space shuttle's cargo bay, disappointed by the failure of the first large-scale test of tethered space flight.

title: Partners Preferred Yield II reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included charges of $ 15,000 in the quarter and $ 40,000 in the 6 months, both related to reorganization.

title: Syncor International reports earnings for Qtr to May 31
Numbers Are Getting Grim for the Mets
description: "Imperative is imperative," Manager Jeff Torborg said before tonight's game against the Pirates.

title: Anacomp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 382,000 for the quarter and $ 1,284,000 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary tax credit of $ 2,000,000, or 5 cents a share, and $ 5,000,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 395,000 for the quarter and $ 1,314,000 for the 9 months, and an extraordinary tax credit of $ 2,000,000, or 4 cents a share, and $ 7,400,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Heart Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Heart Technology said that the loss in the latest quarter is primarily due to costs associated with the voluntary recall of its Rotablator system, announced in June 1992. About $ 4.5 million of the loss is comprised of management's estimate of the one-time costs associated with the recall. The company also said the majority of the costs are related to the writeoff of Rotablator system units returned from the field and in its inventory.

title: Lawn Mower Is New Target In War Against Air Pollution
description: To most people, it is a lawn mower, but to the Environmental Protection Agency it is an "uncontrolled mobile source" that becomes part of the suburban swarm adding measurably to smog on a summer's day. And the time has come, the agency says, to clean it up, along with weed eaters, leaf blowers, chain saws and a lot of other off-road gas-powered machinery.

title: Derlan Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 922,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 682,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 6 months.c-Included income of $ 26,000 and a loss of $ 182,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, both from discontinued operations.Preferred share dividends exceeded net income in some periods.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: ERO Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a charge of $ 1,177,000 relating to an acquisition for both the quarter and 6 months, and 6 months also included an extraordinary charge of $ 1,558,000 from prepayment of debt.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 5,000 in the quarter, and $ 70,000 for the 6 months.

title: General Motors Acceptance Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that in the first six 6 months of 1991, GMAC had a one-time $ 331.5 million gain from accounting changes. With the gain, GMAC had first-half net income of $ 920.8 million.GMAC is a unit of General Motors Corp.

title: New Way To Store More Data
description: A team of researchers at American Telephone and Telegraph's Bell Laboratories said today that they had demonstrated a new computer data-storage technique that can hold nearly 100 times more data than a compact disk and 300 times more data than current magnetic storage systems.

title: New Campaigns
description: * New varieties of Nabisco's Ritz Bits, cheese pizza and nacho cheese come to life in animated commercials created by McCann-Erickson, New York. The spots, produced by Will Vinton Studios, Portland, Ore., show tiny crackers dancing to ethnic tunes like "The Mexican Hat Dance" and "Funiculi-Funicula." * Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate company, compares itself to legends like Babe Ruth, Marilyn Monroe and Albert Einstein in a print campaign created by Poppe Tyson Advertising and Public Relations, New York. The ads carry the theme "There are legends. And those that try to be."

title: Mandela Takes His Message to Apartheid's Citadel
description: Nelson Mandela led a huge and orderly throng of black protesters to the capital of apartheid today to raise the flag of the African National Congress on the front porch of the white Government and demand that President F. W. de Klerk make way for majority rule.

title: Air Express International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago share earnings for the quarter and 6 months are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid July 31.

title: A Top Event: NBC's Dash for Ads
description: It is as obvious to note the barrage of commercials inundating viewers of NBC's coverage of the 1992 Summer Olympics as it is to note the absence of the Soviet Union from the Games. But one advocacy organization has gone to the trouble of documenting the creeping -- nay, galloping -- commercialism of an event whose original purpose had more to do with good will than good marketing.

title: Giants' Line Shuffle Is Blocked So Far
description: William Roberts, his recent irregular heartbeat still unexplained, watches the Giants practice and waits to resume work. Jumbo Elliott, his injured back having failed to respond to therapy and exercise, has entered a hospital with little idea of how soon he will return. Eric Moore, still unsigned and absent, has delayed the team's plan to move him from right guard to right tackle.

title: Dinkins Aide to Join the Clinton Campaign
description: Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch Jr., Mayor David N. Dinkins's chief political aide, will take a leave of absence to serve as deputy director of the state Presidential campaign of Gov. Bill Clinton, having received the Mayor's blessing.

title: MC Shipping Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Democrats; There They Go Again: Clinton and Gore Climb Back on Bus for a 3-Day Trip
description: Having their act together, Bill Clinton and Al Gore are taking it on the road again.

title: Scorpion Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Mobil Oil Corporation was in the corporate debt market yesterday with a $250 million debenture offering through Merrill Lynch.

Serving Software Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Energy Ventures reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
F.B.I. Takes Second Look At Evidence In Conviction
description: The Justice Department has ordered the F.B.I. to take a new look at evidence used to convict a former immigration official imprisoned for conducting illegal searches of Hispanic-owned businesses in Washington Heights, senior law-enforcement officials in New York said.

title: A Strong Hand for Aid to Russia
description: Economic reformers in President Boris Yeltsin's Government are losing ground and the survival of their program is at stake. The West's too diffuse, too slow support for reform has not worked. Though it may be too late, new and quick efforts, directed by the Group of Seven industrial countries, are needed. Without U.S. leadership, which requires passage of the Freedom Support Act by the House, none of them would be effective.

title: Cubs Dismiss Executives
description: The Chicago Cubs yesterday dismissed DICK BALDERSON as vice president for scouting and player development, and BILL HARFORD as director of minor league operations.

title: MBIA Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: MBIA said that results for the first half of 1991 were reduced by 22 cents a share because of a $ 12.6 million addition to loss reserves.Revenue represented total revenues.

title: If You Play With Heroin, It's Going to Get You
description: To the Editor:

title: Thomas B. Nolan Is Dead at 91; A Shaper of U.S. Geologic Survey
description: Thomas B. Nolan, who is credited with shaping the modern missions of the United States Geologic Survey in his 68-year career at the Federal agency, died on Sunday at the George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 91 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Ragen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 2,000 in the quarter and $ 21,000 in the 9 months, and after an extraordinary charge of $ 2,000 in the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $ 1,278,000, or 16 cents a share, in the 9 months, related to restructuring and settlement of long-term debt.c-Net lossd-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 333,000 in the quarter and $ 1,574,000 in the 9 months, and both periods also included a $ 208,000 litigation award.

title: A Compromise on Radio Station Ownership
description: The Federal Communications Commission took the middle road today on radio ownership, bowing to opposition from Congress and the radio industry itself.

description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $ 12,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $ 52,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 6 months.c-After an extraordinary tax credit of $ 21,000, or 1 cent a share, and $ 51,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: For Americans, A Day to Forget At the Olympics
description: It was not merely that the United States lost today on the world's Olympic stage in two sports it invented -- baseball and basketball -- or that it was defeated twice by athletes from the splintered remains of the Soviet Union.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; WPP Gets a Second Chance As Holders Clear Debt Plan
description: SHAREHOLDERS of WPP Group P.L.C. voted overwhelmingly yesterday at a special meeting in London to approve a plan that extensively restructures its crushing debt.

title: NAVY ALTERS PLAN FOR NOVEL PLANE
description: Touching off a new debate over the V-22 Osprey, the tilt-rotor aircraft, the Pentagon said today that it would ask contractors to develop a cheaper derivative of the plane.

title: Lewis and Powell Qualify
description: Carl Lewis might be having his troubles as a sprinter, but there is nothing wrong with his long jumping. In his first and only attempt in the qualification round of the Summer Olympics tonight, he jumped 28 feet 5 3/4 inches, more than two feet beyond the automatic qualifying distance to gain the final Thursday night.

title: Union Energy reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Preferred-share dividends were $ 505,000 in the latest quarter, compared with $ 1,873,000 in year-ago period.The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Consumers Water reports earnings for 12mo June 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,800,000, or 26 cents a share.c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $ 4,279,000.Year-ago's income from continuing operations of $ 10,045,000, or $ 1.65 a share, included gains of $ 3.1 million from sales of properties.

title: Cauthen's Ban Is Extended
description: The American jockey STEVE CAUTHEN went to British Jockey Club headquarters yesterday in London to fight a controversial whip rule that had already landed him a four-day riding ban. He failed, and was given an extra six days for a second offense.

title: Escalade Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to July 11
Puerto Rico Prices Bonds In $310 Million Financing
description: The Commonwealth of Puerto Rico priced $310 million in general obligation bonds yesterday through competitive bidding won by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE increased life span of Americans over the last century has brought joy to many families. But while many older people are healthy and productive to the end, those who fall ill tend either to recover quickly or to stay sick for longer periods than they would have a generation or two ago. In 1900, only 1 in 10 couples between the ages of 40 and 60 had 1 or more of their parents still alive. Ninety years later, 56 percent of couples that age had at least 2 parents alive.

title: Allegre, Jets' Kicker, Keeps Job Quest in Sober Perspective
description: Raul Allegre doesn't know what the ultimate pressure is, but he doesn't think a last-second field goal with a chance to win a game is it.

title: Travelers Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $ 2.9 million, or 3 cents a share, in the quarter and 6 months.c-After an extraordinary tax charge of $ 7.3 million.Travelers Corp. said that its latest second quarter included net realized investment gains of $ 8 million, including a $ 20 million addition to reserves for potential real estate losses. The year-ago second quarter included net realized investment gains of $ 4 million.

description: TRC Cos. said that its results for fiscal 1992 reflect a higher tax rate for the company compared with fiscal 1991, which benefited from greater use of tax loss carryforwards.

title: Drugstore Gadgets or Objects d'Art?
description: A HUMANE mousetrap is among the 189 objects in "Out of the Ordinary," a show in Miami of well-designed objects that are available in places like drugstores, hardware stores and gas stations, for $20 or less. The juried show, with objects designed within the last decade, was organized by the Arango Design Foundation in Miami and recently opened at the Center for the Fine Arts.

title: American Water Works reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Overpricing of Olympics' Triplecast Service Is Acknowledged
description: With sales for the beleaguered Olympics Triplecast drastically below the anticipated level, Chuck Dolan, the chairman of Cablevision, said yesterday that he and his partners at NBC misinterpreted research that convinced them that more people would buy the pay-per-view venture. He said that the faulty projection caused them to overprice the product.

title: Michigan Selling 'Super Sinkers'
description: A $208.95 million bond offering by the Michigan State Building Authority was tentatively priced yesterday through Prudential Securities, with a maximum yield of 6.05 percent for an issue due in 2010.

title: Zairians Debate a Return to 'Congo'
description: Delegates to a national political conference in Zaire have voted to change the country's name back to the Republic of the Congo, the name that it was called until October 1971.

title: Yankees Tonic for Last-Place Indians
description: The Cleveland Indians, the last-place Indians, the Indians who seem to have been rebuilding their club every year since 1954 strolled into Yankee Stadium this week and outplayed the struggling tenants. Someone raise the rent.

title: Electro Brain International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Gaining a Perspective on Binoculars
description: BINOCULARS played a leading role in the Alfred Hitchcock movie "Rear Window," in which a convalescing photographer spies on a neighbor whom he suspects of murder.

title: MedGroup Inc. reports earnings for Year March 31
description: MedGroup said that its 1992 results included a charge of $ 368,600 for the termination of two employment agreements and the closure of its California administrative offices.

title: Paul D. Butcher, 62; Leader in the Gulf War
description: Vice Adm. Paul D. Butcher, retired, who capped 43 years in the Navy by helping to organize the movement of American forces to the Persian Gulf region, died on Monday at his home in Tampa, Fla. He was 62 years old.

description: b-Included an income-tax benefit of $ 72,000, and offset by an extraordinary charge for reversal of benefit of net operating loss carryforwards.

A colleague at F.I.T., HAROLD KODA, director of the design laboratory, has been named associate curator.

description: b-After a charge of $ 142,892 from an adjustment in accounting.

Editor of Spy Is Moving To New York Observer
description: The New York Observer said yesterday that Susan Morrison, the executive editor of Spy magazine, would become its editor. Joe Conason, a former political columnist and staff writer at The Village Voice, was named the executive editor. The Observer, a weekly newspaper, said they would assume their positions in the next few weeks.

Ameriflora: An Odd Hybrid Struggles
description: IT takes guts to set out in a ship when you don't know where you're going. You may arrive at something big -- like America -- and fill your coffers with gold.

title: Harry L. Hansen, 80, Professor of Business
description: Harry L. Hansen, a retired professor at Harvard Business School who was a major figure in the development of advanced business programs throughout the world, died on Monday at Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass. He was 80 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Banks Cite Expense in Refusing State I.O.U.'s
description: Bank of America was not the first bank in California to stop accepting the state government's i.o.u.'s, but because of its huge network of 1,435 branches, the decision by the largest bank in the state was a particularly inconvenient to state workers, creditors and local governments.

description: b-Net income

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans; Bush Jabs at Rival's Morals, Saying Values Are Besieged
description: President Bush today put religion and morality at the heart of his effort to undermine public trust in Gov. Bill Clinton, suggesting that the Democratic nominee lacks the moral fiber to be President.

title: A Raised Eyebrow On the Street
description: IN the Fairmount Park neighborhood of San Francisco, there is a house whose pediment looks like eyebrows. One of the brows is arched, as if to ask its neighbor a question. "The house has an anthropomorphic quality," said Jeremy Kotas, its co-designer with Skip Shaffer.

title: People
description: * Joseph P. Durrett, 46 years old, was named president and chief operating officer at Advo Inc., Windsor, Conn., succeeding John Birk, who left. Mr. Durrett was previously a senior vice president of sales at Kraft General Foods, Glenview, Ill.

description: Jon Schueler, a painter of large-scale abstractions known for their strong evocations of nature, died yesterday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 75 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Mallaig, Scotland.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: IN addition to frequent sweeping or vacuuming, rugs and carpets need regular attention to the pile, prompt action to remove spills and thorough cleaning about once a year. Antique, hand-knotted and other fragile rugs require special handling (for example, some are too delicate for frequent vacuuming and should be swept instead), but ordinary rugs and carpeting made of synthetics or wool are easy to maintain.

title: Focus of Knights of Columbus Is Abortion
description: A proposal to erect a "tomb of the unborn child" in every Roman Catholic diocese in the country has become a symbol of the anti-abortion mood at this week's convention of the Knights of Columbus, the 1.5 million-member Catholic fraternal organization.

William Maxwell McCord, 61, Author and Sociology Professor
description: Dr. William Maxwell McCord, an author on social and urban issues and a sociology professor at City College of New York, died on Monday at Yale University Health Services Center in New Haven. He was 61 years old and lived in Guilford, Conn.

title: Sports of The Times; In Defense Of the Ugly Americans
description: YOU have got to be kidding. People back in the States are saying we're a bunch of spoiled whiners and losers? Get serious, man.

title: No Headline
description: "Comrades, the day when we will install our true president is very near. We are just at the door of the Union Buildings. Next time, next time, F. W. de Klerk, we are going to be inside, inside your office." -- CYRIL RAMAPHOSA, Secretary General of the African National Congress. [ A1:5. ]

title: Mr. Walsh, Pack Up Your Tent
description: The decision of Lawrence E. Walsh, the Iran-contra independent prosecutor, not to indict Ronald Reagan raises a stark question. Now that the man who was ultimately responsible for the scandal has escaped prosecution, what's the point of going on?

title: Treasury Plans $36 Billion Auction
description: The Treasury as expected announced yesterday that it would auction $36 billion of Treasury notes and bonds next week, including $10 billion of 30-year bonds. But this decision appeared to surprise some investors in the bond market, who were apparently looking for some unexpected twist.

title: Braun's Credentials
description: To the Editor:

title: REPORTED PLAN TO BUILD STEEL MINI-MILL IS DENIED BY USX
description: The USX Corporation, the nation's largest steel producer, yesterday denied reports that its steel division had established definite plans to build a steel mini-mill. An article in The Wall Street Journal yesterday reported that sites in Kentucky and Tennessee were being considered for the plant and that the operation would be built next year. Thomas Usher, president of the company's U.S. Steel division, said in a telephone interview that several mini-mill technologies were under consideration but that no decisions had been made about what technologies would be employed, where such a plant would be situated or what markets it would serve.

description: A front-page article last Thursday about the indictment of Clark M. Clifford in New York misstated his relationship with the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau. Both men worked for President John F. Kennedy, but they do not know each other.

title: Riders Grab Medals, But Horses Steal Show
description: There is a little-known event in the Olympics where stars with names like Chevalier and Gigolo show their class by performing piaffes, pirouettes and flying changes. And when they triumph, they stand by, nodding -- occasionally even dribbling -- as others collect the medals.

description: Postmaster General Marvin T. Runyon plans to announce Friday that the United States Postal Service's management will be restructured and trimmed of thousands of jobs through the early retirement of headquarters workers, a postal official said tonight.

title: Topics of The Times; History's Mystery -- for $599
description: The cover of the fall catalogue for New York City's upscale Hammacher Schlemmer emporium features a model of Columbus's flagship, the Santa Maria, priced at a cool $599. Each model took "a minimum of 450 man hours to create," the catalogue declares, and was "faithfully reproduced by hand on the island of Hispanola [ sic ] (where Columbus first set foot)."

title: Last Chance
description: Here is a sampling of shows, performances and art exhibitions in the New York metropolitan region that are to close soon: Closing This Weekend "A STREETCAR NAMED DESIRE," Barrymore Theater, 243 West 47th Street, midtown Manhattan. Tennessee Williams's drama, directed by Gregory Mosher and starring Jessica Lange, Alec Baldwin and Amy Madigan. Last performance: Sunday at 3 P.M. Other performances: today at 8 P.M.; Saturday at 2 and 8 P.M. Tickets: $40 to $50. Information: (212) 239-6200. "MORE-THAN-ONE PHOTOGRAPHY: WORKS SINCE 1980 FROM THE COLLECTION," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, midtown Manhattan. Works from 61 photographers. Through Sunday. Hours: today through Sunday, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $7.50; $4.50 for students and the elderly; free under age 16. Information: (212) 708-9480. "PUSS IN BOOTS: THREE CENTURIES OF THE MASTER CAT," Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, Murray Hill. Illustrations and manuscripts of the classic fairy tale, including an original 1695 manuscript by the author of the story, Charles Perrault. Through Sunday. Hours: today and tomorrow, 10:30 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sunday, 1 to 5 P.M. Suggested admission: $5; $3 for students and the elderly. Information: (212) 685-0008. Closing Next Weekend "FIRES IN THE MIRROR: CROWN HEIGHTS, BROOKLYN AND OTHER IDENTITIES," Joseph Papp Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street, Greenwich Village. A one-woman show featuring Anna Deavere Smith; directed by Christopher Ashley. Through Aug. 16. Performances: Tuesday through Friday at 8 P.M.; Saturdays at 7 and 10 P.M., and Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets: $20. Information: (212) 598-7150.

title: Senators Say Navy Misled Congress on Radar Jammer
description: After being assured by the Pentagon that a controversial new weapon system would undergo stringent tests, lawmakers said today that standards for the $2 billion electronic jamming device, intended to protect fighter jets, had again been eased by the Navy.

title: Brascan Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Earnings per share reflect lower preferred share dividends in 1992 as a result of the retraction of $ 157 million of Series -B- and -C- preferred shares on June 30, 1991.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Suncoast Savings & Loan Assn.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Now, Federal Review of the King Case
description: The stunning acquittals of four officers on state criminal charges of using excessive force against Rodney King brought riots and ruin to Los Angeles in April. President Bush's shocked reaction spoke for many Americans. A Federal grand jury has now brought civil rights charges against the officers, making good on Mr. Bush's pledge for vigorous Justice Department action. A Federal courtroom is an appropriate forum to try this case; it scarred the nation as well.

title: EDO Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from repurchase of debt of $ 59,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: B.P.'s Shares Plummet After Dividend Is Slashed
description: British Petroleum said yesterday that it would cut its dividend by 55 percent, take a pretax restructuring charge of $1.82 billion for the second quarter and lay off 11,500 employees, or 10 percent of its worldwide work force. The moves came five weeks after Robert B. Horton, B.P.'s chairman, resigned under pressure from the company's outside directors.

title: Vintage Petroleum Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Rosset Beats A Weary Ivanisevic
description: After 10 days of sighs about slow surfaces, inconvenient timing and creature discomforts, the real Olympics came to the tennis courts at Vall d'Hebron today. They began with the 46th-ranked player in the world blowing kisses to the sky as he drank in a standing ovation for his upset of a close friend, and they marched into the shadows on the shouts of a hometown for its last remaining son.

title: Yankees Get That Sinking Feeling
description: The Yankees have to wonder when it will end. Can they continue to spiral into oblivion, tumbling lower in the standings and grasping for anything positive during this torturous stretch? After yesterday's sorry effort against the Boston Red Sox, maybe they can.

title: Refugees From Camps Tell of Agony and Terror
description: Refugees from northern Bosnia and Herzegovina say their agony began in late May, when Serbian forces stormed into dozens of towns and villages in what the refugees describe as an operation of singular brutality.

title: INSIDE
description: Political Tactics and Attacks

title: Gulf Canada Resources Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 24,000,000 and $ 25,000,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,000,000 for the quarter and $ 4,000,000 for the 6 months, and both the quarter and 6 months included an after-tax gain of about $ 60 million from the sale of the company's working interest in the Caroline field.Results are in Canadian dollars.The company said in the year-ago results some figures are restated.

title: Relatives Cracked Serial-Killing Case
description: In a story that could come out of a mystery novel, the critical breakthrough in the arrest of Nathaniel White, who has confessed to killing six people, came not from any of the four police departments that were investigating the slayings.

title: Town Says No Thanks To Curbside Mail Drops
description: HERE in ZIP code 07090, where nearly every variety of tree has a street named for it and nearly every street seems to have been an ancient breeding ground for gracious colonial architecture, mail carriers make their way down sidewalks and up front stoops, just as they have for generations.

title: Biocircuits reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said shares outstanding are pro forma; assuming the conversion of all convertible preferred stock for the entire period. The preferred shares were converted at the completion of the company's initial public offering in May.

title: Arden Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: b-Included second quarter 1992 pretax gain from the sale of property of $ 500,000 for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Weston (George) Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an after-tax gain of $ 30 million from the issue of shares by a subsidiary, in the quarter and 6 months.Results are in Canadian dollars.The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: U.S. Puts 2 Fighters In Medal Finals
description: After being involved in two of the disputes that have marked this Olympic boxing competition, and coming up on the losing side, the United States received a break today -- sort of.

title: FRP Properties Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Review/Film; Low Aspirations for High Youths
description: "London Kills Me" is about the lives of a group of young London druggies and pushers toward the end of the Thatcher era. Clint is a pusher who wants to get a straight job. His best friend aspires to an association with the mob. Sylvie, a pretty addict, sort of loves both the men but not enough to kick the habit. In various combinations, they wander around Portobello Road, and on one special day they take a trip to the country.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: REGION COULD GAIN MILLIONS FOR TRANSIT

title: Bottom Is Rushing Up at Yankees
description: So it has come to this, as the days of quiet desperation visit the Bronx once more.

title: Why Are Russians Still Here? the Free Baltics Ask
description: Russia's slow and uncertain withdrawal of its troops from the three Baltic states is adding new poison to a relationship already polluted by unresolved legacies of Soviet rule.

title: Suspect in Payroll-Truck Robbery Arrested
description: A suspect has been arrested on a conspiracy charge involving the attempted robbery of a payroll truck and murder of a security guard in front of a Brooklyn bank last week, Federal authorities announced yesterday.

title: Ivax Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Ivax Corp. said all 1991 figures have been restated to reflect the pooling-of-interest mergers of Willen Drug Co., DVM Pharmaceuticals Inc. and Waverly Pharmacetuical Ltd.

title: United Cos. Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Art in Review
description: 'Miauhaus' Thread Waxing Space 476 Broadway (between Broome and Grand Streets) SoHo Through tomorrow

title: Western Financial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
EIP Microwave Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net income

title: Rumor and Justice in Washington Heights
description: Soon a grand jury will decide whether to indict Officer Michael O'Keefe in the death of Jose Garcia, the shooting that precipitated rioting in Washington Heights in July. Mayor David Dinkins must prepare this confused and outraged community and all New Yorkers for the possibility that Officer O'Keefe might not be indicted.

title: From Aztec Dances to Chinese Martial Arts, the Joys of Cultural Confusion
description: Jenneth Webster, the director of the annual Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival, has mapped out a tour of the world this weekend, complete with meal breaks, that should appeal to just about every interest. For those who would otherwise be watching the Olympics from Barcelona, there will be a pre-Columbian ball game and Chinese martial arts. No jaunts to exotic places will be necessary, for there will be Aztec dance from Mexico and a splashy carnival from the Caribbean. And to draw out confirmed homebodies, Jazzmobile is providing a little string music, and Brenda Bufalino and her American Tap Dance Orchestra will join forces with the Jiving Lindy Hoppers from London for some jamming, jumping and jazz.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Jazz Passengers

title: Plan Creates Jobs for Some On Welfare
description: Seeking to increase the ranks of people who must work for their welfare grants, New York State will begin creating thousands of temporary part-time jobs for single and childless welfare recipients next month.

title: Hewlett Warns On Earnings
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said yesterday that earnings for its third fiscal quarter, which ended July 31, would fall below analysts' expectations.

title: Croatia Gives Petrovic Chance to Be a Leader
description: For Drazen Petrovic, there were two major differences between this suburb of Barcelona and East Rutherford, N.J. One was that the stands were full. The other was that the stands were happy. Exuberant might be a better word.

title: Guadalcanal, Aug. 7, 1942. And Forever.
description: If you were a young Marine 50 years ago, seeing Guadalcanal for the first time from a troopship, your view was spectacular. It seemed evocative of Baudelaire's "Les Fleurs du Mal" -- beautiful and sinister. Except for occasional patches of shoulder-high razor-sharp grass, the island was swathed in tropical rain forest that, from the ship's deck, looked solid enough to walk on.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: The Republicans; Bush Says Rival Would 'Pull a Fast One' Over Taxes
description: Trying to steady the Republicans' wobbly conservative base, President Bush today made his most aggressive assault yet on Gov. Bill Clinton, asserting that the Democratic nominee would "pull a fast one on the American people" and raise taxes by hundreds of billions of dollars.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League CHICAGO WHITE SOX -- Clamed Scott Hemond, catcher-outfielder, on waivers from the Oakland Athletics. Optioned Warren Newson, outfielder, to Vancouver of the Pacific Coast League. Placed Bo Jackson, outfielder, on the emergency disabled list. KANSAS CITY ROYALS -- Signed Juan Samuel, second baseman. Optioned Terry Shumpert, second baseman, to Omaha of the American Association.

title: MEXICANA AIR OWNERS ARE SAID TO BID FOR CONTINENTAL
description: The owners of Compania Mexicana de Aviacion bid for Continental Airlines, an attorney involved in Continental's bankruptcy case said. The attorney, who requested anonymity, said the offer was from Mexicana's owners, not from the airline itself. Miguel de Lascurain, finance director for Mexicana, said he was not aware of any bid. The amount of the offer was unavailable, but a stipluation approved by United States Bankruptcy Judge Helen Balick requires any new bid for Continental to total at least $385 million. The minimum bid was part of an agreement last month between Continental and a group of investors led by Maxxam Group Inc. to acquire 72% of the airline for $350 million. Judge Balick earlier gave preliminary clearance to the agreement, but the I.B.M. Credit Corporation, a major Continental creditor, has appealed that ruling.

title: McGriggs Is in Position To Be Giants Starter
description: A year ago, Lamar McGriggs was a floundering rookie safety, an eighth-round draft choice who made the Giants mainly because he was such a big hitter on special teams. Now he is a year older and many years wiser, and he is pushing Greg Jackson and Myron Guyton for a starting job.

title: Joule Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Delta Settles Complaint of Bias
description: Delta Air Lines has agreed to hire a man who said he had been turned down for a job because he is gay and H.I.V.-positive in a settlement announced yesterday by the New York City Human Rights Commission.

title: National Education reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Allstate Financial reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
IRAQ TO BAR U.N. FROM MINISTRIES
description: Two days before an international inspection team is scheduled to arrive in Baghdad for another round of weapons searches, Iraq announced today that it would bar the inspectors from all its ministries.

title: Itel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 700,000 for the quarter and $ 5,800,000 for the 6 months, and an extraordinary charge from early retirement of $ 24,100,000 and $ 28,400,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.c-After income of $ 1,000,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and a loss of $ 23,500,000 for the 6 months, both from discontinued operations and the 6 months also included an extraordinary credit from early retirement of debt of $ 8,900,000, or 25 cents a share.Latest quarter and 6 months' losses from continuing operations of $ 20,500,000 and $ 25,000,000, respectively, both included charge of $ 21.8 million, reflecting severance and other expenses related to company's restructuring after its recently completed railcar lease transaction.

title: TRAINING CAMP REPORT
description: Washington Redskins

title: Algoma Central reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net lossResults are in Canadian dollars.

title: MILLIONS PROPOSED FOR NEW YORK AREA IN U.S. TRANSIT BILL
description: The New York region would receive hundreds of millions of dollars in Federal mass-transit subsidies, along with money to upgrade its rail systems, under the transportation bill now moving toward approval in Congress.

title: Reviews/Film; Merrily Dealing and Double-Dealing in Hollywood
description: In the opening scene of "Mistress," Barry Primus's deliciously spiky satire of life on the fringes of the movie business, Marvin Landisman (Robert Wuhl), a failed screenwriter and director, sits in his darkened Los Angeles apartment morosely studying Jean Renoir's film classic, "Grand Illusion." His cinematic reverie is interrupted by a phone call from Jack Roth (Martin Landau), a once-successful producer reduced to grasping at straws. Jack excitedly tells Marvin he has found a possible backer to finance a movie from an abandoned screenplay of Marvin's, which he has just re-read and insists is "more timely than ever."

title: Pomeroy Computer Resources reports earnings for Qtr to July 4
description: Year-ago figures are pro forma. The company went public April 10, 1992.

title: Woody Allen's Next: A Murder Mystery
description: A husband and wife find themselves in the middle of a murder mystery in Woody Allen's new romantic comedy, titled "Manhattan Murder Mystery," which is to begin production next month in New York City.

title: Dale R. Bauer; Publishing Executive, 64
description: Dale R. Bauer, a magazine publishing executive, died on Wednesday at his home in Quogue, L.I. He was 64 years old.

title: Critic's Notebook; First There Was Camp; Now There's Cheese
description: TO teen-agers and members of the 20-something generation, Cheese isn't simply something that comes on top of a pizza or burger; it's an esthetic concept, what Camp was to an earlier generation in the 60's.

title: General Motors Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After a $ 749.4 million charge related to Hughes Aircraft restructuring for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6 months also included the unfavorable effect of an accounting change of $ 40 million, of which $ 32.8 million was applicable to GM common stock and $ 7.2 million was applicable to class H common stock.c-Included the favorable effect of accounting changes of $ 539.2 million, of which $ 533.2 million was applicable to GM common stock; the accounting changes had an unfavorable effect of $ 6.1 million applicable to class E and a favorable effect of $ 12.1 million, or 13 cents a share, applicable to class H.

title: Manitowoc Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 27
description: Manitowoc noted that it scrapped some crane inventory, disposed of unprofitable product lines, provided for certain severance agreements, and reserved for a landfill restoration. These items took about $ 4 million from pretax earnings in fiscal 1992, $ 1.5 million of which related to the fourth quarter.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Scandinavian and Casual

title: Gibraltar Mines reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Kansas City Life Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CBI Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
Market Place; High-Risk Debt From the Old Days
description: IN the bad old days, when Drexel Burnham Lambert was a feared investment banking powerhouse and deals were done on the assumption that operations of acquired companies would dramatically improve, pay-in-kind bonds became a Wall Street rage.

title: Fingerprints Introduced in Trial of Ex-C.I.A. Man
description: Prosecutors in the trial of Clair E. George presented a fingerprint expert today to buttress their contention that the former Central Intelligence Agency official deleted passages from his planned testimony to Congress to mislead lawmakers about the agency's role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Agencies to Merge In New England
description: In the latest in a series of agency mergers in New England, Lawner Reingold Britton & Partners and Arnold Fortuna Lane & Cabot in Boston said yesterday that they would combine, creating a shop with estimated billings of $200 million.

title: Northeast Federal reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included income of $ 1,022,000, or 17 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting, and after an extraordinary credit of $ 64,000, or 1 cent a share.Per share amounts are after preferred stock dividend requirements of $ 1,346,000 in the 1992 quarter and $ 2,146,000 in the 1991 quarter.

title: Geico Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split on May 20.Geico Corp. said the latest quarter results included net realized investment gains of $ 26.5 million, or 37 cents a share, compared with $ 6.2 million, or 9 cents a share, in year-ago period.Results for the latest 6 months included net realized investment gains of $ 34.7 million, or 48 cents a share, compared with $ 5.5 million, or 8 cents a share, in year-ago period.Share earnings investment gains figures have also been restated for the 5-for-4 stock split.

title: Woman's Quest for Fame Ends in Death in the Night
description: It was, last week, just another gruesome, unsolved murder in Manhattan: a nameless teen-age girl, shot in the head, her nude body stuffed into a plastic garbage bag and dumped in a parking lot in Chelsea in the dead of night.

title: Oh, for Olga or Nadia, or Even a Little More Kim
description: Oh, oh. NBC's Olympics ratings are no longer spectacular. After a wonderful first week, when ratings peaked with last Thursday night's 22.3, those nettlesome Nielsens fell for three straight nights beginning Sunday, before the decline was stemmed with a 15.8 Wednesday.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 588 money market mutual funds decreased by $5.75 billion, to $504.55 billion, in the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 216 institutional funds decreased by $4.59 billion, to $195.81 billion. The assets of the 282 general-purpose funds were down by $355.7 million, to $170.69 billion. The 90 broker-dealer funds decreased by $802.0 million, to $138.05 billion, the institute said.

title: Coors Testing New Beverage
description: Advertising for a different kind of alcoholic beverage, which is to be tested by the Coors Brewing Company, strives to establish what the product is not as much as what it is.

title: Article 524992 -- No Title
description: The Lower Colorado River Authority, Texas, is selling $291.8 million of bonds to finance the refunding of debt securities previously sold when interest rates were higher.

title: Tepid Recovery in TV's Up-Front Market
description: IF the up-front market for television advertising time is any indication, the economic recovery is tepid at best. Network executives estimate that the four networks took in about $3.5 billion, or roughly the same amount as last year, in advance sales of advertising time in the new television season.

title: Horsehead Resource reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS No. 109 during 1991.

title: TRW PLANS TO REVAMP ITS SPACE AND MILITARY UNIT
description: TRW Inc. said yesterday that it would reorganize its space and military unit beginning Jan. 1, which could eliminate 100 to 150 jobs. The reorganized unit will consist of three operating groups rather than the current four, and the head of each group will report directly to Joseph T. Gorman, chairman and chief executive, TRW said. The reorganization follows changes begun in 1988 as TRW balanced staff against workload amid declining United States military budgets, a spokesman said. The work force in the space and military unit has declined to fewer than 22,000 employees from 32,000 four years ago, he said. Under the reorganization, the electronic systems and space and technology groups will be combined, with Timothy W. Hannemann as executive vice president and general manager. The avionics and surveillance group will continue to be headed by Robert J. Kohler, vice president and general manager, and the systems integration group will continue to be led by John P. Stenbit, vice president and general manager.

title: AUTODIE, A TOOL AND DIE MAKER, FILES UNDER CHAPTER 11
description: The Autodie Corporation, a maker of large-scale tools and dies, said yesterday that it had filed under Chapter 11 of Federal bankruptcy law. "Company officials will continue to work with customers, lenders and potential buyers with the intent to sell the company," Autodie said. Autodie is trying to obtain financing so it can complete work in progress using Autodie employees. Last week, Autodie told 400 employees not to return to work after the company failed to reach an accord with its lenders. The company said it needed additional funds to meet the payroll.

title: Croatia's Mission Impossible: Beat the U.S.
description: The game Croatia had to win is behind it. The game the United States can't fathom losing will be played Saturday night.

title: Review/Art; African and American, A Modernist With Roots
description: The career of the black American artist William H. Johnson (1901-1970) ended abruptly in 1947 when he was confined to Central Islip State Hospital on Long Island for a psychiatric disorder. Despondent and withdrawn, he never left the hospital or painted again. Although the art he left behind suggests many shifting states of mind, despondency is seldom one of them. Rather, it gives evidence of an ambitious artist energetically tackling the issues of 20th-century painting between the world wars, and arriving at a style that combined European modernism with a vernacular American content. This approach defines the work of a number of Johnson's contemporaries -- Marsden Hartley, Jacob Lawrence and Stuart Davis, among them -- but it is the way Johnson mixed and weighted those ingredients that gives his art its distinction.

title: CHIPS AND TECHNOLOGIES PARES A PRODUCT LINE
description: Chips and Technologies Inc., a San Jose, Calif., semiconductor maker, said yesterday that it planned to stop developing future versions of stand-alone Intel-compatible microprocessors and focus instead on integrated chips that combine additional functions with the microprocessor. Analysts said that Chips and Technologies might be the first victim of the price collapse in the market for the Intel Corporation's 386 chip since competition arose from Advanced Micro Devices Inc., the Cyrix Corporation and Chips and Technologies. Chips and Technologies said it would continue to market its existing 386-compatible chip.

title: House Democrats Pass Bill To Aid Families in Trouble
description: Seizing the Republican banner of "family values," House Democrats today passed legislation intended to keep troubled families together and prevent them from going hungry.

title: Universal Corp.  reports earnings for Year June 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 32.3 million. The period also included a loss of $ 3.8 million on the writeoff of a tobacco sale to Iraq.

title: Calloway's Nursery Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraorinary credit of $ 93,000, or 2 cents a share, which includes a gain from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Site in Mexico Could Unlock Ancient Riddle
description: Lost in a remote canyon, asleep beneath a blanket of pasture grass, an ancient city known only to a few farmers and ranchers has been identified by archeologists as a possible answer to one of the least-understood riddles of Mexico's past.

title: DAXOR SHARES DROP; INVESTORS SAID TO BE WARY OF BID
description: Shares of the Daxor Corporation fell $3, or 26 percent, to $8.625 yesterday. The stock's volume on the American Stock Exchange was 547,100 shares, compared with a three-month average daily volume of 84,600. Joseph Feldschuh, chairman, said he knew of no news pending. He attributed the activity to nervous investors reacting to recent developments surrounding an offer by the Resimmo Corporation to buy all, or at least 55 percent, of Daxor for $20.25 a share in cash. Byron Snider, a fund manager with Dimensional Fund Advisors Inc., which holds 172,100, or 3.28 percent, of Daxor's shares, also said he knew of no news that would account for the activity in the stock. Daxor operates a frozen-sperm bank and a frozen-blood bank where individuals can store body fluids for future use. It has also asked the Food and Drug Administration for clearance to market a device to measure human-blood volume.

title: Reviews/Film; Many Moods, and Outfits to Match
description: A peaceful playground. A pleasant day. And two parents making small talk as they watch their children and then share a ride home. Dr. Carter Nix (John Lithgow), a child psychiatrist taking time off from his work to help bring up his daughter, engages a female friend in small talk about the legitimacy of conducting psychological studies on small children. The conversation starts innocently, but within moments -- during the course of an edgy, sustained driving shot executed with bravura ease -- it turns hostile enough to make Carter sneeze. Even worse, it makes Carter commit murder.

title: Docucon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House; Bush's Campaign Dismisses 4 Speech Writers
description: The Bush/ Quayle campaign, aware of the President's need to craft a message with broadened appeal, has dismissed a group of speech writers as part of a continuing effort to get the Republican Presidential campaign on track.

title: Gifts Are Out as an In to Host Status
description: For the International Olympic Committee, enough is enough. So yesterday, the secretary general of the I.O.C. said the organization would no longer allow its members to accept gifts of any kind from representatives of cities bidding for future Games.

title: Standard Commercial Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After extraordinary tax credits of $ 181,000, or 2 cents a share, in latest first quarter and $ 473,000, or 6 cents a share, in year-ago period.

title: Western Groups to Help Yemen Jews to Emigrate
description: A major effort is under way by French, British and American Jewish organizations to organize a discreet departure from Yemen of some 1,600 to 1,700 Yemeni Jews, the last of an ancient community that once numbered 50,000.

title: Democrats Deferring Abortion-Rights Legislation
description: Congressional Democratic leaders said today that they had all but given up this year on trying to pass legislation that would guarantee broad abortion rights because they could not block amendments that would allow state restrictions.

title: Mediq Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $ 4,285,000 for prepayment of debt, and a $ 4,013,000 pretax gain from the sale of Mediq Care Inc., both for the quarter; the 9 months included an extraordinary charge of $ 5,750,000.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 3,469,000, or 14 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 5,776,000, or 24 cents a share, in the 9 months.

description: Todd Webb Houk Friedman Gallery 1094 Madison Avenue, at 82d Street Upper East Side Through Aug. 28

title: A Revamping For Olympia
description: Olympia & York Developments Ltd. said today that the best way to restructure its business would be to negotiate separate loan-refinancing agreements with each of its six creditor committees.

title: CCL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Physicians Insurance Co. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Addenda listing on the Media Business page on Wednesday about the Haworth Group misidentified the site where William F. Heimann will be general manager. It is the newly opened Chicago office; Minnetonka, Minn., is the company's home base.

title: Commerce Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
As for Rights, Bork Follows Madison
description: To the Editor:

title: Oak Hill Sportswear Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
COMPANY NEWS
description: A & W BRANDS INC. will begin selling a noncarbonated drink next month designed to compete with Gatorade and similar products. Called Everlast, it is designed to replace body fluids lost during physical exertion. BMW MOTORRAD G.M.B.H., Munich, said the prices of its motorcycles in Germany would rise 1.8 percent on average beginning Aug. 10.

title: Tejas Gas Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-After income of $ 2,290,000, or 33 cents a share, from required change in method of accounting for income taxes.

title: Article 796992 -- No Title
description: Ninety years have passed since Vincenzo Crisci opened his Italian restaurant on this quiet block near the border between Greenpoint and Williamsburg, and it seems as if not a lot has changed around here since.

title: Bias Found Widespread In the Courts
description: A task force set up to study the New Jersey judicial system has found widespread bias and a lack of opportunity for racial and ethnic minorities to work in the system or receive even-handed treatment from it.

title: Michael Merritt; Set Designer, 47
description: Michael Merritt, an award-winning set designer for movies and plays, died on Aug. 3 at his home in Chicago. He was 47 years old.

title: LVI Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 21,000 for the quarter and $ 75,000, or 1 cent a share, for the 6 months.c-Net lossd-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 2,881,000 for the quarter and $ 5,925,000 for the 6 months, and the 6 months also included an extraordinary credit from early extinguishment of debt of $ 13,293,000, or $ 2.02 a share.LVI Group said that the latest quarter figures reflect results from its nationwide asbestos abatement business and its electrical supply distribution business since the company disposed of its discontinued business segments in 1991.

title: First Chattanooga Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
The Price of Punishment in Delaware
description: John P. O'Connell's job is to try to make sense of Delaware's correctional system and to advise its elected officials on proposed policies and legislation. His work is a major reason that experts cite the state as a leader in the national effort to rein in the costs of dealing with criminals.

title: For Mets, Hardly a Fearsome Showing
description: A forfeit tonight might have ended it more efficiently for the Mets. It's unlikely it would have ended it any less eventfully.

title: Talks Focus on Environment In Push for Free Trade Pact
description: Canadian, Mexican and American trade negotiators labored over the environmental section of a North American free trade agreement today, trying to put the finishing touches on a deal that President Bush could announce Friday, people involved in the negotiations said.

title: Art in Review

title: Few Choices, Fewer Hopes Bush, Under Pressure, Now Talks About Guns
description: President Bush crept reluctantly to the verge of a military commitment in the Balkans today, forced to reconsider his cautious policy by reports of Serbian atrocities, by the prodding of Democratic campaign rivals and by the opposition of senior figures in his own party.

title: Players in Daily News Survival Nearing Final Stages of Battle
description: Like an intricate chess match, the six-month battle of wits and strategy among newspaper unions, prospective buyers, creditors and management over who will own The Daily News is reaching its final stages.

title: Bristol Journal; These Youths Are Sparks, Living in a Powder Keg
description: It began senselessly, the ways suchthings often do. Two young men stole a police motorcycle and, in the ensuing chase, were killed. Spurious rumors spread that the police in this west England city had deliberately run them down, and an angry crowd soon gathered.

title: Washington Practices Defense and Diplomacy
description: Before it can be completely asked, Marvin Washington dismisses a question about Dennis Byrd's working at what used to be Washington's starting left defensive end position.

title: His Best Years Past, Veteran In Debt Sells Oscar He Won
description: Harold Russell, the one-time meat cutter who lost both hands during World War II and went on to win an Academy Award for playing a disabled veteran in the 1946 film "The Best Years of Our Lives," auctioned off his Oscar to help pay bills last night, despite pleas from the award's sponsors, who said no winner had ever sold an Oscar.

title: Accounts
description: * No Touch North America, Irvine, Calif., to Dailey & Associates, Los Angeles, to handle advertising for the No Touch tire-care products account, previously at Basso & Associates Advertising and Public Relations, Costa Mesa, Calif. The account, with billings estimated at $6 million to $9 million, was awarded without a review. * Disney Store Inc. Glendale, Calif., to Rubin Postaer & Associates, Santa Monica, as the Disney retail chain's first national advertising agency. Billings were not disclosed, nor were the names of other agencies that participated in a review on the account. Rubin Postaer also handles advertising for other Walt Disney operations like the company's cable television channel and film-licensing unit.

title: It's Brains Over Bronze as Clever Cuba Reaches Final
description: It was meant to be an all-power semifinal between the two big-hitting teams of the women's Olympic volleyball tournament, but in the end it was the soft touch that won. Cuba beat the United States tonight simply because it showed finesse instead of muscle at just the right moment.

title: Lillian Vallish Foote; Producer, 69
description: Lillian Vallish Foote, a theater and film producer who worked closely with her husband, the playwright Horton Foote, died on Wednesday in Princeton, N.J. She was 69 years old and had homes in New York City and Wharton, Tex.

Review/Theater; Lerner and Loewe Visit the California Gold Rush
description: For Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe, "Paint Your Wagon" was a rare attempt at dealing with Americana, in this case the California Gold Rush. Buoyed by a soaring score, the 1951 musical ran for a season on Broadway, but even after the initial engagement, Mr. Lerner continued to revise it. As author and lyricist, he never stopped tinkering with "Paint Your Wagon." When the show was finally made into a movie 18 years after it opened, Mr. Lerner discarded his original book and wrote a new one, at least partly to accommodate the talents of his stars: Lee Marvin, Clint Eastwood and Jean Seberg.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: FOOTBALL Knox II Debut Is a Hit for Rams Jim Everett threw two touchdown passes and Mike Pagel passed for another as the Los Angeles Rams opened their second era under Coach Chuck Knox with a 21-7 victory over the Seattle Seahawks last night at the Kingdome in Seattle. Knox left the Seahawks following last season after coaching them for nine years. Tom Flores, the former Raiders coach, made his Seahawk coaching debut. The Rams intercepted Kelly Stouffer and Dan McGwire once apiece and also recovered a fumble by Stouffer. (AP)

title: For Children
description: Very little can stop serious beachgoers. Bad weather and poor cash flow may keep some home, but never for long. You can tell them by the way they rattle off the names of every Jersey Shore town by heart (along with the parking rates in each town). They can describe the color and texture of sand with a geologist's expertise. To avoid traffic, they rise at dawn and get to the beach early, leaving at midday or staying late, past the time everyone else has left. They love to feel the water lap up against their skin, to luxuriate in the soft embrace of the sand, to keep up their tans, dangerously.

title: Court That Attacks Sex Bias Is Reported Often Guilty of It
description: Although the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has taken the lead among the nation's courts in condemning sex discrimination, a new survey suggests that the court, and the Federal courts in its domain, do not always practice what they preach.

Inner-city pupils, especially African-American and Hispanic children, are being cheated in their efforts to use computers as learning tools.

title: Pound Foolish on Census Data
description: Census trends and economics statistics make for eye-glazing conversation. Yet they are vitally important to policy makers, scholars, corporate executives and anyone else trying to make sense of the economy. That's why the House and Senate budget bills are alarming: They propose making deep cuts in the Census Bureau and Bureau of Economic Analysis, agencies in charge of keeping statistical tabs on the U.S.

description: Anyone who has seen a child suddenly choke or vomit or lose his breath because he's swallowed something to which he's allergic has probably witnessed an anaphylactic reaction. These reactions kill several hundred young Americans each year, many of whom were unaware they were eating a substance lethal to them.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a chart on Saturday about the 1990 census gave differing rates of population growth for the New York metropolitan area during the 1980's. The rate of 3.1 percent, cited in the article, reflects growth in the area when its boundaries are held constant. The rate of 12.2 percent, listed in the chart, reflects growth when the area is expanded beyond its 1980 boundaries, to 1990 boundaries as defined by the Census Bureau.

title: Bush Urges U.N. to Back Force to Get Aid to Bosnia
description: Responding to mounting international and domestic pressure to take action on the Balkan war, President Bush called today for a United Nations resolution authorizing the use of force to deliver food and medicine to the besieged populations of Bosnia and Herzegovina.

title: UNITED AIRLINES PARES FARES TO HAWAII AN AVERAGE 30%
description: Lower air fares extended westward as the UAL Corporation's United Airlines said it would cut its prices to Hawaii an average of 30 percent this fall. Fliers must buy tickets by Aug. 31 and at least 14 days in advance for trips between Sept. 14 and Dec. 14. The fare cut is the latest in a round of discounting that began last week with an average 30 percent cut on domestic prices. The cuts spread this week to trans-Atlantic routes and the Caribbean. A Delta Air Lines Inc. spokesman said officials were studying the discounts but planned to lower fares to stay competitive. Other airlines did not immediately return telephone calls after the fare cuts were disclosed late Wednesday. With the discount, a round-trip ticket between Chicago and Honolulu will cost $489, down from $730. The New York-Honolulu fare will drop to $569 from $720. The tickets are nonrefundable.

title: Not Tough Enough With Serbia
description: President Bush, under pressure from Bill Clinton and public opinion, has quickened his response to the carnage in the Balkans. He will ask the United Nations to authorize military protection for deliveries of food and medicine. That's commendable but hardly enough to end the savagery.

title: People
description: * David Ogilvy, as expected, retired yesterday as chairman at WPP Group P.L.C., London. Mr. Ogilvy, 81 years old, was named president emeritus and will serve as a consultant. Gordon Stevens, 66, succeeded Mr. Ogilvy as chairman. He is chairman at Scholl P.L.C., London, a position he will retain. * Jann Baskett was named marketing services director at Texas Monthly magazine, Austin, Tex., succeeding Gail Kirsh Susholtz, who left the magazine. Ms. Baskett was previously a freelance creative director and promotion consultant in New York.

title: As the Flame Flickers, a Sense That Sport Will Never Be the Same
description: Olympic officials and athletes of the former Soviet Union drank a symbolic farewell toast to the old system tonight, and welcomed a million-dollar sponsor to try to keep afloat the fractured remains.

title: Jeffrey Porcaro, Toto's Drummer, And a Studio Musician, 38, Dies
description: Jeffrey T. Porcaro, a rock musician who played drums for Sonny and Cher, Bruce Springsteen and the Grammy Award-winning group Toto, died on Wednesday in Los Angeles. He was 38 years old.

title: Review/Film: Unforgiven; A Western Without Good Guys
description: TIME has been good to Clint Eastwood. If possible, he looks even taller, leaner and more mysteriously possessed than he did in Sergio Leone's seminal "Fistful of Dollars" a quarter of a century ago. The years haven't softened him. They have given him the presence of some fierce force of nature, which may be why the landscapes of the mythic, late 19th-century West become him, never more so than in his new "Unforgiven."

title: Southwest Orders $1.2 Billion in Boeing Jets
description: The Boeing Company said today that it had agreed to sell 34 of its 737-300 jets to the Southwest Airlines Company for $1.2 billion.

title: At the Bar; From the mountains to the prairie to the oceans white with foam, a law firm sells itself.

Or that some televised, inside-the-Beltway brawl like the McLaughlin Group was brought to you by Covington & Burling. Or that "L.A. Law" was sponsored by a real Los Angeles law firm like O'Melveny & Myers.

title: MOTOROLA PLANS TO BUY CHIPS FROM MITSUBISHI ELECTRIC
description: Motorola Inc. said yesterday that it would buy chips from the Mitsubishi Electric Corporation to sell in Japan under the Motorola name. Motorola, which makes chips, will buy 4-megabyte dynamic random access memory chips, used for storing data on computers. Neither company would say how many chips would be sold under the agreement. Semiconductors have been the focus of a major trade dispute between Japan and the United States. The agreement between Motorola and Mitsubishi will allow the Japanese to contend that they are buying more United States brand-name chips without actually importing more of them.

While sales exceeded analysts' expectations in some cases and disappointed in others, they failed over all to give any clear indication of the long-awaited rebound in consumer spending.

title: Review/Opera; New Setting of Goethe's Melancholy Love Story
description: When "The Sorrows of Young Werther" was published in 1774, it triggered in European sensibilities a near-mania for its young author and the people he wrote about. Readers were fascinated not only by a story of love and suicide, but also by the story of the story. For Werther, the thwarted lover, was Johann Wolfgang von Goethe himself. Lotte and Albert were his flesh-and-blood summer friends. Only the suicide was borrowed, although from neighboring if unrelated events.

Due to this change, the first half of 1992 consists of 26 weeks, compared to 24 weeks in 1991, and the second quarter of 1992 consists of 13 weeks, compared to 12 weeks in 1991.

title: Operations Show Profit For G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had an operating profit of $392 million in the second quarter -- its most heartening quarterly showing in two years. The company reported a net loss of $357.1 million for the quarter because of the previously announced charge of $749.4 million by its Hughes Aircraft subsidiary.

title: House Votes Billions in Aid to Ex-Soviet Republics
description: After 45 years of voting for foreign aid to combat the Soviet Union, the House voted today to provide billions of dollars in assistance to Russia and the other former Soviet republics.

title: Sico Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to June 26
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Candidates On Television    The Presidential campaigners have scheduled these television appearances in coming days:  Vice President Quayle    TODAY: 5 P.M., C-Span, tape of speeches at campaign stops in Ohio.
description: Gov. Bill Clinton and Senator Al Gore

title: SERBIAN ARTILLERY POUNDS SARAJEVO
description: At about the time that President Bush was toughening his stand on the Bosnian war, Serbian nationalist forces today mounted one of the heaviest artillery assaults in weeks on the central districts of Sarajevo that have taken the brunt of Serbian attacks.

title: 3 Assault Officer at Automated Teller Machine
description: An off-duty police sergeant was assaulted by three men at a Citibank automated teller machine early yesterday morning in mid-Manhattan, the police said.

title: Books of The Times; Mysteries That Reveal More Than Just Whodunit
description: White Butterfly By Walter Mosley 272 pages. W. W. Norton. $19.95. Alibi for an Actress By Gillian B. Farrell 250 pages. Pocket Books. $19.

title: Moore Products reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The company said that the 1992 six months included a nonrecurring pretax, non-cash gain of about $ 2,511,000 from the settlement of benefits related to a previously announced early retirement offer. The period also included a cumulative pretax, non-cash charge of about $ 2,587,000, or $ 1,572,000 net of tax, for a change in accounting as required by FASB Statement No. 106.

title: A Getaway on a Ship of Stateliness
description: THE newest pedigree in Connecticut belongs to the Mayflower Inn, a glamorous place better suited to those who came over on the Concorde than to more traditional pilgrims. Situated just outside the pristine village of Washington, this hideaway gives the old traditions of innkeeping a decidedly new spin. Extravagantly renovated, it boasts an instant supply of the trappings one might associate with a grand old country homestead. That is, if the grand old country were located at the center of Ralph Lauren's imagination, and if most of its antique polish were brand new.

title: U.N. Meets With Rival Factions in Somalia
description: United Nations representatives arrived in the ruined Somali capital today and began talks with rival factions to assess the need for security forces to protect an international relief operation.

title: U.S. Is Tracking AIDS-Like Illness
description: Federal health officials have set up a national surveillance system for cases of an AIDS-like illness in people who show no evidence of infection with the two viruses that are known to cause AIDS -- H.I.V.-1 and H.I.V.-2.

title: Banned American Explains Use of Drug
description: The American hammer thrower Jud Logan left Barcelona today after failing a drug test at the 1992 Olympic Games.

title: European Snack Venture Is Set
description: Pepsico Foods International and General Mills Inc. won approval yesterday from the European Commission for a joint venture, called Snack Ventures Europe, they had proposed in May.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
description: The share earnings in the latest periods of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Co. were $ 1.28 in the quarter and $ 3.14 in the 6 months, compared with $ 1.12 and $ 3.10 in the year-ago periods, respectively.The Shell Transport and Trading Co.'s share earnings in the latest periods were 65 cents in the quarter and $ 1.59 in the 6 months, compared with 57 cents and $ 1.57 in the year-ago periods, respectively.Sales represented sales proceeds.Royal Dutch and Shell Transport are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mets Close To a Trade
description: The Mets, refusing to concede the season, are on the verge of completing a trade for an outfielder the organization trusts can offer enough offense for the club to survive the absences of Bobby Bonilla (fractured rib) and Howard Johnson (fractured right wrist).

title: Reviews/Film; The Clash of Cultures And Dreams Unrealized
description: On the surface, the rough-edged style and down-and-out characters of Claire Denis's second feature, "No Fear, No Die," make this film seem radically different from her exquisitely beautiful, fluid "Chocolat." But "No Fear" is about much more than its small-time heroes: two black immigrants in France who train and sell birds for illegal cockfights. As she did in the 1988 "Chocolat," the partly autobiographical story of a French girl growing up in Cameroon, in "No Fear" Miss Denis shows how the details of daily life carry the weight of a whole lifetime, even a culture. This film is exquisite in its own tough-minded way.

title: Learning Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to June 30
CHRONICLE
description: A dramatized documentary based on the experiences of former hostages in Beirut has provoked the anger of three of those hostages, TERRY WAITE, BRIAN KEENAN and JOHN McCARTHY.
